By focusing on the latent change scores, LCSM allows researchers to assess how much individuals change over time and to explore the factors that drive this change. Unlike traditional growth models that focus on modeling trajectories using slopes and intercepts, LCSMs directly capture the change between successive time points. This approach models the change itself as a latent variable, capturing individual differences in growth rates and providing insights into the dynamics of the change process. By directly modeling these latent changes, LCSM enables the examination of relationships between changes in different variables over time."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"In LCSMs, the change between measurements is treated as a latent construct, enabling the separation of true change from measurement error. This approach allows researchers to model the factors influencing change scores, such as the effect of time-varying covariates, and to examine individual differences in change processes. By specifying the relationships between initial levels, change scores, and covariates, LCSMs provide a flexible framework for testing hypotheses about the mechanisms driving change over time."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"Latent Change Score Models are particularly useful when the interest lies in understanding the dynamics of change itself rather than just the overall trajectory. They can accommodate non-linear patterns of change and are capable of modeling reciprocal effects between variables over time.
